div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of newspaper clipping, [La Discusion], [November 22, 1900] (See Spanish original)
div1.p:
Yellow fever transmitted to Spanish immigrants
by mosquitos!

New details regarding the horrible
experiment to prove the possibility that
yellow fever is transmitted to a person
through mosquito bites - to which we
referred yesterday- have been
communicated to us.

"The procedure that is employed," writes
an anonymous collaborator, "is not to
release the mentioned insects into the
room where the immigrants sleep."

They have them in glass tubes,wherein
one of the ends is uncapped, applying
them to the body of someone attacked by
the endemic illness. As is natural, the
moquito, forcibly, has to bite the patient;
after which the mosquito is again
captured, and after a day has passed, the
same procedure is performed on a
healthy person. If the healthy person
becomes sick shortly afterwards, the bite
has transmitted the illness. In the
opposite case, the experiment serves to
show that it is not one of the methods of
infection.

"Also," continues our anonymous
informant," other methods are
being tested to see how a healthy
man can become infected. To that
end, immigrants are given-destining
them for their use-the bed clothes
that have served the sick during
the course of their illness.

"The most unheard of is" -the letter
ends this way- "that in some of the
cases the experiment subjects know
perfectly well that they are the object of
an experiment, though without realizing
that this could cost them their lives; but
they accept it in exchange for the offer
of 100 pesos that is made to them."

Up to this point the reports that,without a
true guarantee, we receive, we report.

Our opinion with respect to the act is
already expressed: we hesitate to believe
in its existence; it seems impossible to
us... But it seems impossible at the same
time that it is not proven false through a
scrupulous investigation; and to practice
this arouses the jealousy of the
administrative authorities.
